question: Which of the following is NOT considered a transition element, and why?
options: \text{Zn — its d}^{10}\text{ configuration is complete in both ground and ionic states}
\text{Mn — it has too many oxidation states}
answer: \text{Zn — its d}^{10}\text{ configuration is complete in both ground and ionic states}
tip: Zn, Cd, Hg are called non-typical transition elements — their d¹⁰ is complete and never partially filled.

question: The electronic configurations of Cr and Cu are exceptions to the expected pattern. They are:
answer: \text{Cr: [Ar]3d}^5\text{4s}^1\text{; Cu: [Ar]3d}^{10}\text{4s}^1
tip: Extra stability of half-filled (d⁵) and completely filled (d¹⁰) configurations drives these exceptions.

question: Why is mercury (Hg) a liquid at room temperature, unlike other transition metals?
options: \text{Hg has the highest ionisation enthalpy in the series}
\text{Hg has a completely filled d}^{10}\text{ configuration, no unpaired electrons, and weak metallic bonding}
\text{Hg forms amalgams easily which lower its melting point}
\text{Hg has the largest atomic radius in the series}
answer: \text{Hg has a completely filled d}^{10}\text{ configuration, no unpaired electrons, and weak metallic bonding}

question: The transition metal with the highest melting point and the transition metal with the highest density are respectively:
answer: \text{W (3410°C) and Ir}
tip: Iridium density = 22.61 g/cm³; Osmium = 22.52 g/cm³. Iridium is denser.

question: The magnetic moment of a transition metal ion is 5.92 BM. The number of unpaired electrons and the most likely ion are:
answer: n = 5\text{; Mn}^{2+}\text{ or Fe}^{3+}

question: The purple colour of KMnO₄ is due to charge transfer, not d-d transition. This is because:
options: \text{Mn in KMnO}_4\text{ has a d}^0\text{ configuration with no unpaired d-electrons}
\text{Mn in KMnO}_4\text{ has a d}^5\text{ half-filled configuration}
\text{MnO}_4^-\text{ is too large for d-d transitions}
\text{Mn(VII) has an even number of electrons}
answer: \text{Mn in KMnO}_4\text{ has a d}^0\text{ configuration with no unpaired d-electrons}
tip: Charge transfer: O²⁻ → O⁻ and Mn(VII) → Mn(VI). Only possible when energy levels on two atoms are close.

question: Anhydrous CuSO₄ is colourless, but CuSO₄·5H₂O is blue. This is because:
options: \text{Anhydrous CuSO}_4\text{ has Cu in +1 oxidation state}
\text{In the hydrated salt, water molecules act as ligands causing d-d transitions in Cu}^{2+}
\text{SO}_4^{2-}\text{ causes the blue colour in the hydrated salt}
answer: \text{In the hydrated salt, water molecules act as ligands causing d-d transitions in Cu}^{2+}

question: Which of the following correctly matches the catalyst with its composition?
answer: \text{Ziegler-Natta: TiCl}_4 + \text{(C}_2\text{H}_5)_3\text{Al; Lindlar's: Pd/BaSO}_4\text{; Wilkinson's: [Ph}_3\text{P]}_3\text{RhCl}

question: In a normal spinel structure (e.g. ZnFe₂O₄), which ions occupy which holes?
options: \text{M}^{3+}\text{ in tetrahedral holes; M}^{2+}\text{ in octahedral holes}
\text{M}^{3+}\text{ in octahedral holes; M}^{2+}\text{ in tetrahedral holes}
\text{Both M}^{2+}\text{ and M}^{3+}\text{ in octahedral holes}
\text{M}^{2+}\text{ in octahedral holes; M}^{3+}\text{ in tetrahedral holes (inverse spinel)}
answer: \text{M}^{3+}\text{ in octahedral holes; M}^{2+}\text{ in tetrahedral holes}
tip: Inverse spinel (e.g. Fe₃O₄): M³⁺ in tetrahedral holes, M²⁺ in octahedral holes.

question: The ore of K₂Cr₂O₇ is chromite. In the preparation, chromite is first fused with Na₂CO₃ in air to give:
answer: \text{Na}_2\text{CrO}_4\text{ (yellow)}
tip: Full sequence: chromite → Na₂CrO₄ (yellow) → Na₂Cr₂O₇ (orange, on acidifying) → K₂Cr₂O₇ (adding KCl).

question: In aqueous solution, chromate and dichromate ions are interconvertible depending on pH. In acidic medium:
answer: \text{Cr}_2\text{O}_7^{2-}\text{ (orange) is formed}
tip: Acid → dichromate (orange). Alkali → chromate (yellow). Easy memory: acid = orange, alkali = yellow.

question: Acidified K₂Cr₂O₇ oxidises I⁻ to I₂. The Cr₂O₇²⁻ ion is reduced to:
answer: \text{Cr}^{3+}

question: The ore of KMnO₄ is pyrolusite (MnO₂). In the commercial preparation, MnO₂ is first fused with KOH and oxidised to give:
answer: \text{K}_2\text{MnO}_4\text{ (green manganate ion)}
tip: MnO₂ → K₂MnO₄ (green) → KMnO₄ (purple) by electrolytic oxidation.

question: KMnO₄ is acidified only with H₂SO₄ and not HCl or HNO₃ in titrations. Why?
options: \text{HCl reacts with KMnO}_4\text{ liberating Cl}_2\text{; HNO}_3\text{ itself acts as an oxidising agent}
answer: \text{HCl reacts with KMnO}_4\text{ liberating Cl}_2\text{; HNO}_3\text{ itself acts as an oxidising agent}

question: In acidic medium, KMnO₄ is reduced to Mn²⁺. The half-reaction is:
answer: \text{MnO}_4^- + 8\text{H}^+ + 5e^- \rightarrow \text{Mn}^{2+} + 4\text{H}_2\text{O}

question: The transition metal showing the highest paramagnetism in the 3d series is Mn(II). This is because:
options: \text{Mn(II) has 5 unpaired electrons (d}^5\text{), the maximum possible in a d-subshell}
answer: \text{Mn(II) has 5 unpaired electrons (d}^5\text{), the maximum possible in a d-subshell}

question: In the chromyl chloride test for Cl⁻, the red vapour of CrO₂Cl₂ is passed into NaOH solution. The sequence of observations is:
options: \text{Red vapours} \rightarrow \text{red Na}_2\text{CrO}_4\text{ solution} \rightarrow \text{red PbCrO}_4\text{ ppt on adding Pb(CH}_3\text{COO)}_2
\text{Red vapours} \rightarrow \text{yellow Na}_2\text{CrO}_4\text{ solution} \rightarrow \text{yellow PbCrO}_4\text{ ppt on adding Pb(CH}_3\text{COO)}_2
answer: \text{Red vapours} \rightarrow \text{yellow Na}_2\text{CrO}_4\text{ solution} \rightarrow \text{yellow PbCrO}_4\text{ ppt on adding Pb(CH}_3\text{COO)}_2
tip: CrO₂Cl₂ + 4NaOH → Na₂CrO₄ (yellow) + 2NaCl + 2H₂O. Then Na₂CrO₄ + Pb(CH₃COO)₂ → PbCrO₄ (yellow ppt). Confirms Cl⁻.

question: The composition of German silver is:
tip: German silver contains no silver at all — a common trick question.

question: Non-stoichiometric compound Fe₀.₉₄O exists because:
options: \text{Fe and O have different atomic masses}
\text{Fe exhibits variable oxidation states (+2 and +3), allowing some Fe}^{2+}\text{ to be replaced by Fe}^{3+}
\text{O has a tendency to exist in excess}
\text{The compound is not an oxide but a hydroxide}
answer: \text{Fe exhibits variable oxidation states (+2 and +3), allowing some Fe}^{2+}\text{ to be replaced by Fe}^{3+}

question: Only Os and Ru among transition metals show +8 oxidation state, while Ni and Fe show zero oxidation state in their carbonyls. Which option correctly states both facts?
options: \text{Os/Ru reach +8 in fluorides and oxides; Ni(CO)}_4\text{ and Fe(CO)}_5\text{ have M in zero OS}
\text{Os/Ru reach +8 only in complex ions; Fe(CO)}_5\text{ has Fe in +2 OS}
\text{All transition metals can reach +8; only Ni shows zero OS in Ni(CO)}_4
\text{Os/Ru reach +8 in chlorides; Ni(CO)}_4\text{ has Ni in -2 OS}
answer: \text{Os/Ru reach +8 in fluorides and oxides; Ni(CO)}_4\text{ and Fe(CO)}_5\text{ have M in zero OS}

question: Lanthanoids are called rare earths. Their atomic numbers range from:
answer: 57 \text{ (La) to } 71 \text{ (Lu), 15 elements}

question: The most stable oxidation state of lanthanoids is +3. Some exhibit +2 or +4 because they achieve stable f-configurations. Which set is correct?
options: \text{Eu}^{2+}\text{(f}^7\text{), Yb}^{2+}\text{(f}^{14}\text{) — reducing agents; Ce}^{4+}\text{(f}^0\text{), Tb}^{4+}\text{(f}^7\text{) — oxidising agents}
\text{Eu}^{4+}\text{ and Yb}^{4+}\text{ are the stable +4 ions}
\text{All lanthanoids show only +3 OS; no exceptions exist}
answer: \text{Eu}^{2+}\text{(f}^7\text{), Yb}^{2+}\text{(f}^{14}\text{) — reducing agents; Ce}^{4+}\text{(f}^0\text{), Tb}^{4+}\text{(f}^7\text{) — oxidising agents}

question: Lanthanoid contraction occurs because:
options: \text{4f orbitals are small and shield very effectively}
\text{4f orbitals are large and diffuse with poor shielding; effective nuclear charge increases steadily}
\text{The nuclear charge decreases across the lanthanoid series}
answer: \text{4f orbitals are large and diffuse with poor shielding; effective nuclear charge increases steadily}

question: A direct consequence of lanthanoid contraction is that Zr and Hf, and Nb and Ta have nearly identical sizes. They are called:
answer: \text{Chemical twins}

question: Which of the following is a consequence of lanthanoid contraction?
options: \text{Basic strength of Ln oxides/hydroxides increases from La to Lu}
\text{Basic strength of Ln oxides/hydroxides decreases from La to Lu}
\text{5d series elements are larger than 4d series elements}
answer: \text{Basic strength of Ln oxides/hydroxides decreases from La to Lu}

question: The magnetic moment formula for lanthanoids is different from transition elements because:
options: \mu = \sqrt{4S(S+1) + L(L+1)}\text{ (includes orbital contribution L); for 3d metals orbital contribution is quenched by ligand fields}
answer: \mu = \sqrt{4S(S+1) + L(L+1)}\text{ (includes orbital contribution L); for 3d metals orbital contribution is quenched by ligand fields}

question: Misch metal is used in lighter flints. Its approximate composition is:
options: \text{Lanthanoid metals 94--95\%, Fe 5\%, traces of S, C, Ca, Al}
answer: \text{Lanthanoid metals 94--95\%, Fe 5\%, traces of S, C, Ca, Al}

question: Actinoids differ from lanthanoids in which key respect?
options: \text{Actinoids show variable OS up to +7; have greater tendency to form complexes; actinoid contraction > lanthanoid contraction}
\text{Actinoids have lower tendency to form complexes than lanthanoids}
\text{Actinoids all occur naturally; none are man-made}
answer: \text{Actinoids show variable OS up to +7; have greater tendency to form complexes; actinoid contraction > lanthanoid contraction}

question: Sc³⁺ and Ti⁴⁺ are colourless in solution, whereas Ti³⁺ is coloured. The reason is:
options: \text{Sc}^{3+}\text{ and Ti}^{4+}\text{ have d}^0\text{ configuration — no d-d transitions possible; Ti}^{3+}\text{ has d}^1\text{ — d-d transition possible}
\text{Sc}^{3+}\text{ and Ti}^{4+}\text{ are too small to absorb visible light}
\text{Sc}^{3+}\text{ and Ti}^{4+}\text{ have completely filled d}^{10}\text{ orbitals}
\text{Ti}^{3+}\text{ is coloured due to charge transfer, not d-d transitions}
answer: \text{Sc}^{3+}\text{ and Ti}^{4+}\text{ have d}^0\text{ configuration — no d-d transitions possible; Ti}^{3+}\text{ has d}^1\text{ — d-d transition possible}
tip: Rule: d⁰ and d¹⁰ ions are colourless (no d-d transitions). All others with partially filled d-orbitals are coloured.

question: Why do the 5d transition elements (e.g. Hf, Ta, W) have nearly the same atomic radii as the corresponding 4d elements (Zr, Nb, Mo), even though they are in a lower period?
options: \text{5d elements have fewer electrons than expected}
\text{Lanthanoid contraction: poor shielding of 4f electrons causes the 5d elements to be unusually small, offsetting the expected increase in size}
\text{5d elements have a higher nuclear charge which contracts them}
\text{4d and 5d elements have identical electronic configurations}
answer: \text{Lanthanoid contraction: poor shielding of 4f electrons causes the 5d elements to be unusually small, offsetting the expected increase in size}
